instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.SSD_PWR_EN: What is SSD_PWR_EN? SSD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip making the power rail for the SSD to turn on when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_CONN_L: What is SSD_RESET_CONN_L? SSD_RESET_CONN_L is a signal that goes to the SSD that will put it in RESET mode which will keep it from working, when SSD_RESET_L is present. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing SSD
threads.message:
Hi,

we have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here which is not seeing the SSD. No repair or water damage history, no visible damage to the connector. All pins except GND measure resistance to ground.

<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SSD_PCI_SEL_L</SIGNAL> are 3.4V
Flashed BIOS, replaced SMC

Of course tested with known-good SSD.

Last thing on my mind is the PCH, or am I missing something?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing SSD
threads.message: Boot from a USB into the installer with the SSD plugged in and check in Disk utility. does it see a volume or drive?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing SSD
threads.message: Yeah, tried that of course. Isn't seen at all. Sorry for not mentioning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing SSD
threads.message:
Firstly put back the original BIOS.
Check all caps in the data lines <CAPACITOR>C3710</CAPACITOR> and up. Diode mode on one side and continuity to the connector on the other side. Also inspect for damage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing SSD
threads.message: I had one that wasn't recognizing internal SSD same as OP. I followed Dukes instruction and focused on Capacitors <CAPACITOR>C3710</CAPACITOR> and up. I couldn't figure out how to do a continuity test without an extra set of arms or soldering a jumper wire to each Cap so I re-flowed them and it worked. I never would have suspected them as they were as clean as the rest of the board, it never had a Liquid spill but it was overheating badly when I replaced the display and did a thermal a few weeks earlier.
